John,

Thank you for asking.  As soon as I get the first version completed, I am
thinking I will put up a small site for it.  That way, someone can browse
through the Javadocs and look through some example XML docs of persisted
networks.  As for a design document, I will think about it.  I would prefer
to have most of it in the Javadocs.  I think it will involve less rewriting
and be more self-contained and more likely to be kept up-to-date that way.

I am still doing the rework to incorporate the design changes about which I
talked with Derek and Philip.  I am pretty thoroughly Javadoc-ing as I am
writing the code.  It may be another couple weeks of spare time work before
I am able to thoroughly test the code.  I only get around 5-10 hours a week
to work on my projects.  If all goes well, that will climb to 15-20 here
soon.

Thank you for the feedback on the input node activation function question.
I am feeling more confident about my understanding of the ANN nuances.


Jim


----- Original Message -----
From: "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@...>
To: <neat@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, July 25, 2004 10:46 AM
Subject: RE: [neat] An ANN design question...


> >As I have written previously here, I am working on an optimized ANN
> >implementation in Java which I have named SEMIANN (Sparsely Evaluated
> >Matrix Interace Artificial Neural Network).
>
> If you get a chance and can write up a design document explaining the
> methodology used, I'd like to read it. :)
>
> >It is my understanding from the small number of ANN implementations I
have
> >seen (around 5)
> >including that of David Fogel (author of book titled "Blondie24" from
which
> >I am duplicating
> >experiments), the input data is placed directly into the input node.  The
> >data is not bounded
> >(other than the actual limits of a float or double).  And the input node
> >does *not* have an
> >activation function.  The unbounded data present in the input node is
then
> >used in the activation
> >of the hidden nodes (simple 3 layer feed forward network).  Any sort of
> >altering the input data is
> >then handled by the weight attached to that input node.  The GA process
> >will then drift the
> >weights around such that inputs which are not so valuable are muted with
> >smaller weight values.
> >And inputs which are important are magnified with higher weight values.
> >And all of these weights
> >will eventually form a function over which the input data is "normalized"
> >based on each input's
> >relative importance, a sort of first approximation of the input data's
> >inter-relatedness.
>
> This is what I have seen, as well.  And it is how my Perl version of NEAT
is
> implemented.  Obviously, I didn't port Ken's C++ code to Perl, I took the
> ideas from the papers and re-implemented them.
>
> >In contrast, Philip and Derek indicated an input data point entering
their
> >ANN implementation is
> >actually being pushed through the input node's activation function.  Then
> >the "modified" data
> >point is now placed into the input node.  It is then used in the
activation
> >of the "hidden" nodes.
>
> I'm inclined to think that for a controller, which is what NEAT is most
> often applied to, that the practice of running the input values through
the
> activation function doesn't hurt it much.  But I can easily imagine
domains
> where the practice could render it nearly impossible for NEAT to evolve a
> solution.
>
> >Sidenote: In SEMIANN, I do not allow a connection to have a destination
of
> >an input node.  So
> >there is no need for an activation function at an input node.  And input
> >node is treated as just
> >an unbounded data point.
>
> Ditto for Perl NEAT.
>
>
>
